lines.text:
[in a sticky voice]
I must be going now. Goodbye, Rabbit.
Well, goodbye, if you're sure you won't have any more.

[turns to leave then stops]
*Is* there any more?
No, there isn't.
I thought not.

[tries to climb out the front door but is stuck]
Oh, oh, help and bother! I'm stuck.
Oh, dear. Oh, gracious. Oh. Well, it all comes from eating too much.
It all comes from not having front doors big enough!
Winnie the Pooh crawled out of the gorse bush, brushed the prickles from his nose, and began to think again.
Think, think, think.
And the first person he thought of was...
Winnie the Pooh?

[chuckles]
No, Christopher Robin.
Oh.
Good morning, Christopher Robin.
Oh, good morning, Winnie the Pooh.
Good morning, Pooh bear.
If it is a good morning, which I doubt.

That buzzing noise means something. Now, the only reason for making a buzzing noise that I know of is because you are... a bee! And the only reason for being a bee is to make honey. And the only reason for making honey is so I can eat it.
Why did I ever invite that bear to lunch? Why, oh, why, oh, why?
That sssupercilious ssscoundrel confiscated my honey.
Blast it all.
Good idea! We'll dynamite. Save time.
Eh, what's the charge?
The charge? Oh, about seven sticks of dynamite.
Oh, no, no, no, the cost! The charge in money.
Nope, no charge account. I work strictly cash.
Obviously, but, I should think...
Well, I can't stand around lollygagging all day. I got a tight schedule.

[falls down a hole]
Aaaaaaaahh.
If you think it over, let me know. You got my card, I'm not in the book, you know.
Oh. Dash it all, he's gone.
After all, he's not in the book, you know.
Oh.
There now. Did I get your tail back on properly, Eeyore?
No matter. Most likely lose it again, anyway.
Could you ssspare a sssmall sssmackerel?
Say, you ought to do sssomething about that ssspeech impediment, sssonny.
Pooh, Roo has a little surprise for you.
Flowers.
Honeysuckle!
[Pooh tries to eat it]

[chuckles]
No, Pooh, you don't eat them. You smell them.
Oh.
[smells the honeysuckle]

[nodding head]
Would you like *condensed milk*,

[shaking head]
or *honey* on your bread?
Both. But never mind the bread, please. Just a small helping, if you please.
Huh, there you are.

[gives Pooh a single drop of honey; Pooh looks at him disappointedly]
Is, uh, something wrong?
Well, I did mean a little larger "small helping."

[after rolling in mud]
There, now.
[giggles, then wades out of the mud puddle]
Isn't this a clever disguise?
What are you supposed to be?

[looking himself over]
I'm a little black rain cloud, of course.

[giggles]
Silly old bear.
Thanks. It's not much of a tail, but I'm sort of attached to it.
Oh, stuff and fluff.
[singing]
Hum dum de dum, hum dum de dum / I am so rumbly in my tumbly.

[hits head]
Ooh!

Time to munch an early luncheon / Hum de dum dum dum / Oh, I wouldn't climb this tree / If a Pooh flew like a bee / But I wouldn't be a bear then / So I guess I wouldn't care then / Bears love honey and I'm a Pooh bear / So I do care, so I climb there / I'm so rumbly in my tumbly / Time for something... for something...

[branch breaks]
... sweet! To eat!
Is anybody at home?
[no answer]
What I said was, "Is anybody at home?"
No.
Bother. Isn't there anybody here at all?

[hurriedly collecting dishes from his table]
Nobody!
Must be somebody there, because *somebody* must have said, "Nobody."
Well, isn't that the Rabbit's voice?

[talking into a honey jar]
I don't think so. It isn't meant to be.

[drawing on Pooh's backside when he's stuck in Rabbit's door]
Oh, Pooh! You messed up my moose!
Now, when Pooh heard his pooh-coo clock, he knew it was time for something. But he was a bear of very little brain, so when he thought, he thought in the most thoughtful way he could think.
Christopher Robin... I think the bees - S-U-S-P-E-C-T something.
Perhaps they think you're after their honey.
Well, it may be that. You never can tell with bees.
Oh, bother. Empty again. Only the sticky part's left.

[peering into Rabbit's hole]
Hello, Rabbit!
Oh, oh, hello, Pooh Bear.
[realizes]
Uh, Pooh Bear! Uh, uh, aha, aha, what a pleasant surprise! And, uh, how about lunch?

[entering Rabbit's home]
Oh, thank you, Rabbit.

[lamely]
And uh, help yourself, Pooh.
Well, if it isn't Pooh Bear.
Oh, hello, Owl.
Splendid day to be up and about one's business, eh?
[Notices Pooh is stuck on Rabbit's door]
I say, are you stuck?
No, just resting, and thinking, and humming to myself.
[Hums]
You, sir, are stuck. A wedged bear in a great tightness. In a word, irremovable.
First thing to be done is to get rid of that bear. He's gumming up the whole project.
Dash it all, he *is* the project!
[Pooh notices that his black rain cloud disguise is failing and the bees are after him]
THESE ARE THE WRONG SORTS OF BEES!
Christopher Robin! I think it would help with this deception if you would just kind of open your umbrella and say, "Tut-tut, it looks like rain."
Tut-tut, it looks like rain. Tut-tut, it looks like rain.
Now Pooh wasn't one to give up so easily. When he set his mind to honey, he stuck to it. Now, honey rhymes with bunny, and bunny rhymes with...
Rabbit? I like Rabbit, because he uses short, easy words like, "How about lunch?", and "Help yourself, Pooh."

[Listening from inside]
Pooh? Lunch? Oh, no. Not again. Oh my, oh my, oh my goodness gracious.
Pooh Bear, there's only one thing we can do, wait for you to get thin again.
Oh bother. How long will that take?
Days, weeks, months, who knows?

[hammering a sign in front of Gopher]
Don't - feed - the - bear!
Hmph! I'm gonna skedaddle.

Christopher Robin lived in another part of the forest where he could be near his friends and help them with their problems. On this summer day, gloomy old Eeyore, being stuffed with sawdust, had lost his tail again.
And then, one morning, when Rabbit was beginning to think that he might never be able to use his front door again, it happened!

[after Pooh budges through Rabbit's door a little ways]
He budged! Hooray! Christopher Rabin! Uh, uh, Chrostopher Robin, he bidged! He badged! He booged! Today's the day!

[after Pooh gets stuck in the honey tree again]
Stuck again.
Don't worry, Pooh. We'll get you out.
No hurry. Take your time.
Oh yes, I'm rumbly in my tumbly. Time for something sweet.

[seeing a lunchbox pop up from Gopher's hole]
A lunchbox?

[appearing]
It certainly is. I'm workin' the swing shift, you know.
